alert.note: Alert for Lewis (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued February 28 at 9:49PM PST until March 02 at 1:50AM PST by NWS Seattle
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Washington... Chehalis River Above Doty affecting Lewis County. Chehalis River Above Grand Mound affecting Grays Harbor and Thurston Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Washington... Newaukum River Near Chehalis affecting Lewis County. .Heavy rain over the Central and Southern Cascades will continue into Tuesday morning. The rain will taper off later Tuesday morning into Tuesday afternoon. Temperatures in the lower and mid levels in the mountains are above freezing adding a little snow melt to the runoff. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY WEDNESDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Newaukum River Near Chehalis. * WHEN...Until early Wednesday morning. * IMPACTS...At 204.5 feet, deep and hazardous flood waters will inundate many roads and residential and commercial areas along the Newaukum River and its forks. Impacted roadways and surrounding areas include SR 508, Jackson Hwy. and Tune, Rush, Sommerville, Griel, Hamilton, Tauscher, Guerrier, Kirkland, Macomber, Rice, Senn, Lucas Creek, Middle Fork and North Fork, Bishop, Shorey, Labree, Gish, Yates Roads. A stage of 204.5 feet on the Newaukum roughly corresponds to Phase 3 flood in the Lewis County flood system. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 PM PST Monday the stage was 202.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 205.4 feet late tonight. It will then fall below flood stage Tuesday afternoon. - Flood stage is 202.5 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. Most flood related deaths occur in automobiles. Do not attempt to cross water covered bridges, dips, or low water crossings. Never try to cross a flowing stream, even a small one, on foot. To escape rising water find another route over higher ground. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued by Tuesday morning at 600 AM PST.
